* Plural (`die`): `Ich sehe mein**e** Kinder.`

**Summary Table of Endings:**

| Case | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Nominative** | `-` | `-e` | `-` | `-e` |
| **Accusative** | `-en` | `-e` | `-` | `-e` |

**Example with `sein` (his):**
* `**Sein** Bruder ist nett.` (Nom, m)
* `**Seine** Schwester ist auch nett.` (Nom, f)
* `Ich kenne **seinen** Bruder.` (Acc, m)
* `Ich kenne **seine** Schwester.` (Acc, f)

**Special case `euer` (your):** When it takes an ending, it often drops the 'e': `eure`, `euren`.

### Part 3: In the Dative Case (A Preview)
The pattern continues! The endings are the same as `einem`, `einer`, `einem`.
* `mit mein**em** Bruder` (with my brother)
* `aus dein**er** Tasche` (from your bag)
* `zu unser**em** Haus` (to our house)
mission:
1. Match the pronoun to the possessive: `ich` -> `mein`, `er` -> ?, `sie` (she) -> ?, `wir` -> ?
2. Fill in the blanks with the correct form of `mein`.
    * `Das ist ______ (m, nom) Vater.`
    * `Das ist ______ (f, nom) Mutter.`
    * `Ich liebe ______ (f, acc) Mutter.`
    * `Ich besuche ______ (m, acc) Vater.`
3. Translate: "Her dog is small." and "I see her dog."

*(Answers: 1. sein, ihr, unser. 2. mein, meine, meine, meinen. 3. `Ihr Hund ist klein.` and `Ich sehe ihren Hund.`)*

title: Family Vocabulary
content:
## Lesson 27: The Family (Die Familie)
Today we'll use our new knowledge of possessive articles to talk about one of the most important topics: family!

### Part 1: Core Family Members
Most family member nouns have both a masculine and a feminine form.

| Masculine | Feminine | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| `der Vater` (father) | `die Mutter` (mother) | `die Eltern` (parents) |
| `der Sohn` (son) | `die Tochter` (daughter) | `die Kinder` (children) |
| `der Bruder` (brother) | `die Schwester` (sister) | `die Geschwister` (siblings) |
| `der Großvater / Opa` (grandfather) | `die Großmutter / Oma` (grandmother) | `die Großeltern` (grandparents) |
| `der Ehemann` (husband) | `die Ehefrau` (wife) | `die Eheleute` (married couple) |
| `der Onkel` (uncle) | `die Tante` (aunt) | |
| `der Cousin` (male cousin) | `die Cousine` (female cousin) | |

### Part 2: Describing Your Family
Let's put it all together with possessive articles and verbs we know.
* `Das ist **mein** Vater. **Sein** Name ist Klaus.` (This is my father. His name is Klaus.)
* `Das ist **meine** Mutter. **Ihr** Name ist Monika.` (This is my mother. Her name is Monika.)
* `Ich habe **einen** Bruder. **Er** ist 25 Jahre alt.` (I have a brother. He is 25 years old.)
* `**Meine** Schwester wohnt in Hamburg.` (My sister lives in Hamburg.)
* `Wie heißen **deine** Eltern?` (What are your parents' names?)
* `**Unsere** Familie ist nicht sehr groß.` (Our family is not very big.)

### Part 3: Marital Status (Der Familienstand)
How to describe your relationship status.
* `Ich bin ledig.` - I am single.
* `Ich bin verheiratet.` - I am married.
* `Ich bin geschieden.` - I am divorced.
* `Ich bin verwitwet.` - I am widowed.
* `Ich habe einen festen Freund / eine feste Freundin.` - I have a boyfriend / a girlfriend.

**Dialogue Example:**
> **Alex:** Hast du Geschwister?
>
> **Maria:** Ja, ich habe eine Schwester. Sie heißt Julia. Und du?
>
> **Alex:** Ich habe zwei Brüder. Sie sind älter als ich.
>
> **Maria:** Wohnen deine Eltern auch hier in der Stadt?
>
> **Alex:** Nein, meine Eltern wohnen in einem kleinen Dorf. Mein Vater ist Rentner (retired) und meine Mutter ist Lehrerin.
mission: 1. Draw a small, simple family tree for your own family or a fictional one. Label the people with the German words (`Vater`, `Mutter`, etc.).\n2. Write two sentences about your family using possessive articles. (e.g., `Mein Bruder heißt...` `Meine Mutter arbeitet als...`)\n3. Learn how to say your own marital status in German.
helpfulHint: `Geschwister` is a useful word that doesn't exist in English. If someone asks `Hast du Geschwister?` (Do you have siblings?), you can answer `Ja, ich habe einen Bruder und eine Schwester.`

title: Hobbies and Free Time
content:
## Lesson 28: Hobbies & Free Time (Freizeit)
What do you do for fun? Today you'll learn how to talk about your hobbies and what you do in your free time. This is a great topic for making conversation and getting to know people.

### Part 1: Asking About Hobbies
* `Was sind deine Hobbys?` - What are your hobbies?
* `Was machst du in deiner Freizeit?` - What do you do in your free time?
* `Hast du Hobbys?` - Do you have hobbies?

### Part 2: Talking About Your Hobbies
**Using Verbs:** The easiest way is to just use a verb.
* `Ich lese gern.` - I like to read.
* `Ich koche gern.` - I like to cook.
* `Ich reise gern.` - I like to travel.
* `Ich höre gern Musik.` - I like to listen to music.
* `Ich spiele gern Fußball/Gitarre/Videospiele.` - I like to play football/guitar/video games.
* `Ich treffe gern Freunde.` - I like to meet friends.

**The Magic Word `gern`:**
Adding `gern` (or `gerne`) after the verb is the most common and natural way to say you like doing something.
* `Ich schwimme.` - I swim / I am swimming.
* `Ich schwimme gern.` - I like to swim.

To say you *love* doing something, you can say `sehr gern`.
* `Ich tanze sehr gern.` - I love to dance.

To say you *don't* like doing something, use `nicht gern`.
* `Ich singe nicht gern.` - I don't like to sing.

**Using Nouns:** You can also say "My hobby is...".
* `Mein Hobby ist Lesen.` - My hobby is reading.
* `Meine Hobbys sind Kochen und Reisen.` - My hobbies are cooking and traveling.

### Part 3: More Hobby Vocabulary
* `ins Kino gehen` - to go to the cinema
* `Serien schauen` - to watch series
* `Sport machen / treiben` - to do sports
* `wandern gehen` - to go hiking
* `Fahrrad fahren` - to ride a bike
* `fotografieren` - to photograph
* `im Garten arbeiten` - to work in the garden
* `malen` - to paint
* `tanzen` - to dance
* `schwimmen` - to swim

### Part 4: A Dialogue About Hobbies
> **Jonas:** Was machst du gern am Wochenende?
>
> **Lena:** Am Wochenende schlafe ich gern lange! Und ich treffe gern meine Freunde. Manchmal gehen wir ins Kino. Und du? Machst du Sport?
>
> **Jonas:** Ja, ich spiele gern Tennis. Und im Winter fahre ich gern Ski. Liest du gern?
>
> **Lena:** Ja, ich lese sehr gern, besonders Krimis (crime novels).
>
> **Jonas:** Cool! Ich lese nicht so gern. Ich höre lieber Podcasts.

**`lieber` - to prefer**
`lieber` is the comparative of `gern`. It means 'to prefer to do'.
* `Ich trinke gern Kaffee, aber ich trinke lieber Tee.` (I like to drink coffee, but I prefer to drink tea.)
mission: 1. Learn the phrase `... gern`.\n2. Answer the question in a full sentence: `Was machst du gern in deiner Freizeit?` (Write at least two things).\n3. Ask a friend or family member (in English is fine!) what their hobbies are, and then try to say their answer in German. (e.g., `Meine Mutter kocht gern.`)

title: Putting It All Together: Writing an Email
content:
## Lesson 29: Writing a Short Email
You've learned so much! Today, let's put it all together by writing a short, informal email to a German friend. This will practice greetings, past tense, future plans, and conjunctions.

### Part 1: Structure of an Informal Email
1.  **Greeting (Anrede):**
    * `Hallo [Name],`
    * `Liebe [Female Name],` (Dear...)
    * `Lieber [Male Name],` (Dear...)
    * **Important:** After the greeting, the first word of the email is written in **lowercase**.

2.  **Opening Line:**
    * `wie geht es dir?` (How are you?)
    * `vielen Dank für deine E-Mail.` (Thanks for your email.)
    * `ich hoffe, alles ist gut bei dir.` (I hope everything is well with you.)

3.  **Main Body (Hauptteil):**
    * This is where you write what you want to say. Use the Perfect Tense to talk about your week and modal verbs to talk about plans.

4.  **Closing Line (Grußformel):**
    * `Viele Grüße` (Best regards)
    * `Liebe Grüße` (Warm regards, literally 'love greetings')
    * `Bis bald` (See you soon)
    * **Important:** There is **no comma** after the closing line.

5.  **Your Name:**
    * Just your first name.

### Part 2: Sample Email
Let's analyze a sample email from Alex to his friend Julia.

**Subject: `Wochenende in Berlin`**

`Liebe Julia,`

`vielen Dank für deine E-Mail. Mir geht es sehr gut, aber ich habe viel gearbeitet.`

`Letztes Wochenende war super. Ich bin nach Berlin gefahren, weil mein Freund Geburtstag hatte. Wir haben eine große Party gemacht und viel getanzt. Am Sonntag haben wir ein Museum besucht und am Abend habe ich einen Film gesehen.`

`Nächstes Wochenende will ich zu Hause bleiben und ein Buch lesen. Ich muss auch meine Wohnung aufräumen. Was sind deine Pläne? Fährst du zu deinen Eltern?`

`Ich hoffe, wir können bald wieder telefonieren.`

`Viele Grüße`
`Alex`

### Part 3: Let's Break It Down
* **Greeting:** `Liebe Julia,`
* **Opening:** `vielen Dank...` (Thanks...), `Mir geht es sehr gut...` (I'm doing well...), `aber ich habe viel gearbeitet.` (but I have worked a lot.) - *Perfect tense with `haben`*
* **Paragraph 2 (Past):**
    * `Ich bin nach Berlin gefahren...` - *Perfect tense with `sein`*
    * `...weil mein Freund Geburtstag hatte.` - *Subordinate clause with `weil`*
    * `Wir haben... gemacht und... getanzt.` - *Perfect tense*
    * `Am Sonntag haben wir... besucht und... gesehen.` - *Perfect tense*
* **Paragraph 3 (Future/Plans):**
    * `...will ich... bleiben und... lesen.` - *Modal verb `wollen`*
    * `Ich muss auch... aufräumen.` - *Modal verb `müssen` with a separable verb `aufräumen`*
    * `Was sind deine Pläne?` - *Question*
* **Closing:** `Ich hoffe, wir können bald... telefonieren.` - *Hoping with modal verb*
* **Sign-off:** `Viele Grüße` and `Alex`.
mission:
Write your own short email (4-6 sentences) to a fictional German friend named `Max`.
1. Start with `Lieber Max,`.
2. Say how you are.
3. Write 2-3 sentences about what you did last weekend (use the Perfect Tense).
4. Write 1-2 sentences about what you want to do next weekend (use a modal verb).
5. End with `Viele Grüße` and your name.

title: Final Review & Next Steps
content:
## Lesson 30: Final Review & Your Next Steps!
Herzlichen Glückwunsch! Congratulations! You have completed this 30-day introduction to A1 German. You have built a fantastic foundation. Today is for reviewing the biggest concepts and thinking about where to go from here.

### Part 1: The Core Pillars of A1 German
Let's quickly recap the most important structures you've learned.

**1. Verb Position is King:**
* **Normal Sentence:** Verb in **Position 2**. (`Ich lerne heute Deutsch.`)
* **Yes/No Question:** Verb in **Position 1**. (`Lernst du heute Deutsch?`)
* **Modal Verb:** Modal in **Position 2**, main verb infinitive at the **END**. (`Ich will heute Deutsch lernen.`)
* **Separable Verb:** Stem in **Position 2**, prefix at the **END**. (`Ich rufe dich heute an.`)
* **Perfect Tense:** Helper (`haben/sein`) in **Position 2**, participle at the **END**. (`Ich habe gestern Deutsch gelernt.`)
* **Subordinate Clause (`weil`, `dass`...):** Verb kicked to the **END** of its clause. (`...weil ich Deutsch gelernt habe.`)

**2. The Case System:**
* **Nominative:** The subject. The 'doer' of the action. (`Der Hund` schläft.)
* **Accusative:** The direct object. The 'receiver' of the action. The only major change is `der` -> `den`. (Ich sehe `den Hund`.)
* **Dative:** The indirect object. 'To/for whom'. (Ich gebe `dem Hund` das Futter.)

**3. Gender is Unavoidable:**
* Every noun has a gender (`der`, `die`, `das`). You must learn it with the noun. This affects all the articles (`ein/eine`, `mein/meine`, `den/die/das`, etc.).

### Part 2: A1 Exam Tips
If you are thinking of taking an official A1 exam (like from the Goethe-Institut or Telc), here's what to expect:
* **Hören (Listening):** You'll hear short announcements (e.g., at a train station) and simple conversations. The key is to listen for specific information (a time, a platform number, a name).
* **Lesen (Reading):** You'll read short emails, advertisements, and signs. Again, the goal is to find specific information.
* **Schreiben (Writing):** You will have to fill out a form (name, address, etc.) and write a very short, simple email, just like we practiced yesterday.
* **Sprechen (Speaking):** This is often done in a small group. You will have to:
    1.  Introduce yourself (`Ich heiße...`, `Ich komme aus...`, `Meine Hobbys sind...`).
    2.  Ask for and give simple information (e.g., you get a card with the word `Wochenende` and have to form a question: `Was machen Sie am Wochenende?`).
    3.  Make a request (e.g., you get a card with a picture of a glass of water and have to say `Ich hätte gern ein Wasser, bitte.`).

### Part 3: What's Next? Your Journey to A2
You've built the ground floor. Now it's time to build the next level. A2 German is where you start to feel more comfortable and fluent. Topics include:
* More tenses (the simple past/Präteritum, for reading stories).
* Reflexive verbs (`sich waschen` - to wash oneself).
* Adjective endings (the final big grammar hurdle!).
* More complex sentence structures and conjunctions.
* Comparatives and superlatives (big, bigger, biggest).

**How to Keep Learning:**
* **Consistency is key:** 15-30 minutes every day is better than 3 hours once a week.
* **Consume German Media:** Find German musicians you like, watch children's TV shows (`Peppa Wutz`, `Die Sendung mit der Maus`), or try a 'slow German' news podcast.
* **Speak!** Find a language partner online, talk to yourself in German, or join a conversation group. Don't be afraid to make mistakes. Mistakes are proof that you are trying.
* **Review:** Go back over these 30 lessons from time to time. You'll be surprised how much more you understand the second time around.
